Title: Artificial light at night affects brain plasticity and melatonin in birds
Authors: Stan Moaraf, Yulia Vistoropsky, Tatyana Pozner, Rachel Heiblum, Monika Okuliarová, Michal Zeman, Anat Barnea
Supporting quotes for "Outdoor or indoor:
- "Adult female zebra finches were reared outdoor at the Meier Segals Garden for Zoological Research at Tel-Aviv University, Israel. After reaching adulthood (about 90 days), experimental birds (ranging between 3-5 months of age for all groups) were moved from their native colonies to indoor conditions."
  - "Day length and temperature were set to 27 0 C; 14:10 L:D, and in order to ensure constant and identical conditions within and between groups, temperature, moisture and light intensities were monitored every 10 days in the same points around and in the cage."
  - "The experiment consisted of four groups (see below), six birds per group. Zebra finches are very social species. Therefore, birds in each group were kept in one cage (67 × 33 × 33 cm), to avoid isolation stress. We used one room for the entire experiment, in which the groups were run at a randomized order within a 5-months period."
Reasoning for "Outdoor or indoor":
The paper indicates that the study was conducted in an indoor setting, with the birds being moved from their native outdoor colonies to indoor conditions for the experiment. This is evident from the following quotes:
"Adult female zebra finches were reared outdoor at the Meier Segals Garden for Zoological Research at Tel-Aviv University, Israel. After reaching adulthood (about 90 days), experimental birds (ranging between 3-5 months of age for all groups) were moved from their native colonies to indoor conditions."
"The experiment consisted of four groups (see below), six birds per group. Zebra finches are very social species. Therefore, birds in each group were kept in one cage (67 × 33 × 33 cm), to avoid isolation stress. We used one room for the entire experiment, in which the groups were run at a randomized order within a 5-months period."
"Day length and temperature were set to 27 0 C; 14:10 L:D, and in order to ensure constant and identical conditions within and between groups, temperature, moisture and light intensities were monitored every 10 days in the same points around and in the cage."
These quotes clearly indicate that the study was conducted in an indoor setting, with the birds being moved from their native outdoor colonies to controlled indoor conditions for the experiment.

Title: Bright light at night alters the perception of daylength in Indian weaver bird (Ploceus philippinus)
Authors: Jayant Kumar, Shalie Malik, Sanjay Kumar Bhardwaj, Sangeeta Rani
Venue: Journal of Experimental Zoology Part A Ecological and Integrative Physiology
Supporting quotes for "Outdoor or indoor:
- "Adult male weaver birds were captured from nature and acclimatized in an outdoor aviary (size = 3 × 2.5 × 2.5 m) under natural photoperiod until beginning of the experiment. Thereafter, they were transferred to indoor aviary under 8 hr light: 16 hr dark (short photoperiod; 8L:16D)."
  - "Photosensitive birds (n = 33) were individually housed in specially designed activity cages (60 × 35 × 45 cm) that were placed individually in temperature-regulated (24 ± 2 • C) light-proof wooden chambers (75 × 50 × 70 cm) providing programmed light:dark cycles by compact fluorescent lamps (CFL; 14 W, 230 V, Phillips, India)."
Reasoning for "Outdoor or indoor":
The paper indicates that the study was conducted in both outdoor and indoor environments:
"Adult male weaver birds were captured from nature and acclimatized in an outdoor aviary (size = 3 × 2.5 × 2.5 m) under natural photoperiod until beginning of the experiment. Thereafter, they were transferred to indoor aviary under 8 hr light: 16 hr dark (short photoperiod; 8L:16D)."
The birds were first captured from the wild and acclimatized in an outdoor aviary. Then, they were transferred to an indoor aviary for the actual experiment under controlled light-dark conditions.
"Photosensitive birds (n = 33) were individually housed in specially designed activity cages (60 × 35 × 45 cm) that were placed individually in temperature-regulated (24 ± 2 • C) light-proof wooden chambers (75 × 50 × 70 cm) providing programmed light:dark cycles by compact fluorescent lamps (CFL; 14 W, 230 V, Phillips, India)."
The actual experiment was conducted in these indoor, temperature-controlled, light-proof chambers, indicating an indoor study.

Title: Can skyglow reduce nocturnal melatonin concentrations in Eurasian perch? *
Authors: Franziska Kupprat, Franz H € Olker, Werner Kloas, Sarah Harmon
Supporting quotes for "Outdoor or indoor:
- "The entire experiment was repeated once with a new set of fish directly after the first run to achieve a sufficient amount of replicates for each treatment (n ¼ 6). Hence, there was about a month in between the temporal replication. The experiments were run in October and November 2017."
  - "Juvenile Eurasian perch (Perca fluviatilis) were obtained from Lake Müggelsee (Berlin, Germany) and kept in indoor tanks (ca. 600 L) with natural photoperiod and dark nights for at least two weeks prior to moving into the aquaria of the experimental setup."
  - "Twelve equal aquaria with 80 L tap water were set up in a climate chamber at ca. 17 C (see below for more details)."
Reasoning for "Outdoor or indoor":
The paper describes an indoor, laboratory-based experiment on Eurasian perch. This can be determined from the following quotes:
"Twelve equal aquaria with 80 L tap water were set up in a climate chamber at ca. 17 C (see below for more details)."
This quote indicates that the experiment was conducted in a climate-controlled indoor setting, specifically in aquaria within a climate chamber.
"Juvenile Eurasian perch (Perca fluviatilis) were obtained from Lake Müggelsee (Berlin, Germany) and kept in indoor tanks (ca. 600 L) with natural photoperiod and dark nights for at least two weeks prior to moving into the aquaria of the experimental setup."
This quote further confirms that the fish were kept in indoor tanks prior to the experiment, and then moved to the experimental aquaria within the climate chamber.
"The entire experiment was repeated once with a new set of fish directly after the first run to achieve a sufficient amount of replicates for each treatment (n ¼ 6). Hence, there was about a month in between the temporal replication. The experiments were run in October and November 2017."
This quote indicates that the experiment was conducted over multiple runs in an indoor, controlled setting, rather than an outdoor, field-based study.

Title: Differential response of diurnal and nocturnal mammals to prolonged altered light-dark cycle: a possible role of mood associated endocrine, inflammatory and antioxidant system

Title: LIGHT AT NIGHT CANNOT SUPPRESS PINEAL MELATONIN LEVELS IN THE LIZARD ANOLZS CAROLZNENSZS

  - "Freshly collected anoles were placed under stockroom conditions on 26 July 1985. On 2 August 1985 lizards were placed in terraria in one of two 'C' chambers in the Phytotron on the NCSU campus."
Reasoning for "Outdoor or indoor":
To determine whether the study by Herbert Underwood was conducted outdoors or indoors, I will examine the details provided in the paper:

Title: Role of light wavelengths in synchronization of circadian physiology in songbirds
Authors: G Yadav, S Malik, S Rani, V Kumar
Supporting quotes for "Outdoor or indoor:
- "For this study, birds were captured in late February, brought to the laboratory and acclimated to captive conditions for a week in an outdoor aviary (size = 3 × 2.5 × 2.5 m)."
  - "Photosensitive birds (buntings: n = 14; weaverbirds: n = 18) were housed individually in activity cages (60 × 35 × 45 cm) and placed inside the photoperiodic boxes (size, 75 × 50 × 70 cm) providing programmed light cycles by compact fluorescent bulbs (CFL; 14 W, 230 V, Phillips, India); temperature was maintained at 24 ± 2 °C during the experiment."
  - "Thereafter, they were moved indoors and kept under short photoperiods (8L:16D), in which they remain unstimulated and maintain photosensitivity, until the beginning of the experiment."
Reasoning for "Outdoor or indoor":

Then, they were moved indoors and kept in individual activity cages inside photoperiodic boxes with programmed light cycles.
